metadata.subject: Fwd: Alert: FIRPTA and REIT Reform Provisions in the New Tax Law Open Door to Increased Foreign Investment in U.S. Real Property Interests

organizations: U.S. House Committee on Oversight and Accountability

relationships.description: Kahn is forwarding tax law information to Epstein
Law firm providing tax law updates to clients

analysis.purpose: To inform about significant changes to FIRPTA and REIT tax laws that benefit foreign investment in U.S. real estate
analysis.significance: Details major tax law changes that could significantly impact foreign investment strategies in U.S. real estate

notable_quotes: The PATH Act makes foreign capital investment in U.S. real estate, energy and infrastructure assets more attractive by expanding certain exemptions from FIRPTA
One of the most significant provisions of the PATH Act is the addition of a complete exemption from FIRPTA for 'qualified foreign pension funds'
The PATH Act opens the door to increased investment by expanding the current statutory exemption from FIRPTA for small portfolio investments by non-U.S. persons

blackmail_indicators.description: No indicators of blackmail or coercion present in this professional tax law update

illegal_activity.description: Document is a forwarded legal/tax alert about new legislation, not containing any first-hand illegal activity

public_knowledge.context: Tax law changes affecting foreign investment in U.S. real estate would be of public and media interest

analysis.summary: Richard Kahn forwards a tax law alert from Sadis & Goldberg LLP to Jeffrey Epstein detailing significant FIRPTA and REIT reform provisions in the PATH Act that make foreign investment in U.S. real estate more attractive, particularly for foreign pension funds.
